content: Learn how to configure an NFS server and client for file sharing in Linux. Step-by-step guide to set up NFS server, export directories, and mount them on client machines.
title: How to configure NFS server/client

content: Server bash sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install nfs-kernel-server bash sudo mkdir /nfs_share sudo chown nobody:nogroup /nfs_share sudo chmod 777 /nfs_share Configure NFS share folder(/etc/exports) text /nfs_share 192.168.1.10(rw,sync,no_subtree_check) 192.168.1.10 - ip of NFS client ####export, enable and start NFS share text sudo exportfs -a sudo systemctl enable nfs-kernel-server sudo systemctl start nfs-kernel-server
title: How to configure NFS server/client

content: ClientMount the NFS Share on the Client Machine text sudo mkdir /mnt/nfs_share sudo mount -t nfs 192.168.1.100:/nfs_share /mnt/nfs_share Configure the NFS Share to Auto-Mount at Boot Time(/etc/fstab) text 192.168.1.100:/nfs_share /mnt/nfs_share nfs defaults 0 0
title: How to configure NFS server/client

content: Enable remote access to Postgres Modify the PostgreSQL configuration file text sudo nano /etc/postgresql/12/main/postgresql.conf Then, find the line #listen_addresses = 'localhost' and uncomment it next, change the value of listen_addresses to *. Modify the pg_hba.conf file text sudo nano /etc/postgresql/12/main/pg_hba.conf append next line text host all all 0.0.0.0/0 md5 Restart PostgreSQL text sudo service postgresql restart

content: Learn how to set up Basic Authentication in Nginx to password-protect parts of your website using .htpasswd. Step-by-step guide with examples and security tips.
title: Basic Authentication in Nginx ‚Äî Protect Your Website with a Password

content: Sometimes you need to restrict access to specific areas of your website‚Äîsuch as an admin panel, staging environment, or internal documentation. One of the simplest ways to do this is by enabling Basic Authentication using Nginx. In this guide, you‚Äôll learn how to set up password protection in just a few steps.
title: Basic Authentication in Nginx ‚Äî Protect Your Website with a Password

content: üîß Nginx Configuration Example with Basic Auth config server { server_name site.com; location / { ... auth_basic "Administrator Area"; auth_basic_user_file /etc/nginx/protections/site.com.htpasswd; ... } } auth_basic sets the authentication prompt message (realm). auth_basic_user_file specifies the path to the password file.
title: Basic Authentication in Nginx ‚Äî Protect Your Website with a Password

content: üõ† Installing Utilities & Creating a Password FileFirst, install the tool that allows you to create .htpasswd files: bash sudo apt-get install apache2-utils Now create a new password file and add the admin user: bash htpasswd -c site.com.htpasswd admin Note The -c flag creates a new file, overwriting it if it exists. Don‚Äôt use -c when adding additional users. Move the file to your desired location, such as: bash sudo mv site.com.htpasswd /etc/nginx/protections/ Make sure to test your Nginx configuration and reload it: bash sudo nginx -t sudo systemctl reload nginx
title: Basic Authentication in Nginx ‚Äî Protect Your Website with a Password

content: ‚úÖ Best Practices for Security Store the .htpasswd file outside the publicly accessible directories. For more robust authentication, consider using OAuth, JWT, or integration with a centralized identity provider. Don‚Äôt forget to enforce HTTPS to protect credentials during transmission.
title: Basic Authentication in Nginx ‚Äî Protect Your Website with a Password

content: Learn how to reset your Grafana admin password using grafana-cli. Simple step-by-step CLI guide for login recovery and admin access.
title: How to Change Grafana Admin Password

content: üîê How to Change Grafana Admin PasswordIf you‚Äôve forgotten the admin password in Grafana or just want to reset it for security reasons, there‚Äôs a simple command-line tool you can use to reset it instantly. This guide walks you through changing the Grafana administrator password using the built-in CLI.
title: How to Change Grafana Admin Password

content: ‚ö° Quick Command bash grafana-cli admin reset-admin-password <new_password> Replace <new_password> with your desired secure password. üõë You must run this command as the same user that runs the Grafana service (usually: grafana). üõ†Ô∏è Step-by-Step Instructions SSH into your server or open a terminal if local. (Optional) Stop Grafana: sudo systemctl stop grafana-server Run the CLI password reset: grafana-cli admin reset-admin-password mySecurePassword123 Start Grafana again: sudo systemctl start grafana-server Log in to http://localhost:3000 with: Username: admin Password: mySecurePassword123 ‚úÖ When to Use This Lost or forgot admin password After a fresh install of Grafana After breaking login due to failed SSO/SAML setup Server or container migration üîí Security Tips Use a strong, unique password. Store your credentials in a secure vault (like Vault, 1Password, or Bitwarden). Consider enabling Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) in Grafana for added security.
title: How to Change Grafana Admin Password

content: Learn how to migrate containers from LXC (.raw disk image) to KVM (.qcow2 format) with a step-by-step guide. Convert, optimize, and run your virtual machines seamlessly.
title: How to migrate LXC(.raw) to KVM(.qcow2)

content: To migrate your LXC virtual server to a KVM just follow these steps: For example, we have image.raw based on Ubuntu 18.04.6 We installed a KVM machine with the same operating system, in my case it was KVM server with ssh access to 192.168.1.1 mount image.raw like next: bash mount ./image.raw /mnt/root sync the LXC to the new KVM server bash rsync --exclude=/etc/fstab --exclude=/boot --exclude=/proc --exclude=/lib/modules/ --exclude=/etc/udev --exclude=/lib/udev --exclude=/sys -e ssh --delete --numeric-ids -avpogtStlHz /mnt/root/ root@192.168.1.1:/
title: How to migrate LXC(.raw) to KVM(.qcow2)
